channel.title: Golang Weekly
channel.description: A weekly newsletter about the Go programming language

item.title: „ÄêForget TypeScript, how about porting Doom to Go?„ÄëÂøòËÆ∞ÊâìÂ≠óÁ®øÔºåÁßªÊ§çÂéÑËøêÊÄé‰πàÂäûÔºü
item.description:
„Äê

#‚Äã546 ‚Äî March 19, 2025

Unsub¬†¬†|¬†¬†Web¬†Version

Go Weekly

Traversal-Resistant File APIs ‚Äî Among the lesser known new features in recent versions of Go are some ways to improve file system security when end user input might have an impact on file paths your app tries to access, including os.Root, filepath.IsLocal, filepath.EvalSymLinks and filepath.Localize. A must¬†read.

Damien Neil

Were Multiple Return Values a Mistake for Go? ‚Äî An interesting technical post critiquing the effects of one of Go‚Äôs earliest design decisions. This is an area where opinions will differ strongly, but the author thinks Go sorely needs to support¬†tuples.

Mond

üìÖ Live Workshop: Build Production-Ready Apps with JavaScript & Go ‚Äî Join Maximiliano Firtman next week (online or in-person) for a 3-day workshop, learning how to build real-world, fully functional web apps using vanilla JS & Go. Create performant, scalable¬†apps.

Frontend Masters sponsor

TypeScript's Go Port Already Leading to Optimizations for Go ‚Äî Last week‚Äôs big news was about the TypeScript compiler being ported to Go for performance reasons. A neat side effect of such a large project entering our ecosystem is the increased potential for even more performance improvements for Go¬†itself, something that has already begun to¬†occur..

GitHub Go Repo

Go Structs and Interfaces Made Simple ‚Äî An introduction (or refresher) of Go‚Äôs core building blocks when it comes to working with data types and structs ‚Äì an approach that differs somewhat from those favored in object oriented languages like C++ or¬†Java.

Deven J (Stream)

üìÑ Benchmarking: What You Can't Miss in Go 1.24 Jakub Jarosz

üìÑ How GitHub Engineers Learn New Codebases Brittany Ellich (GitHub)

üì∫ How to Implement Server-Sent Events in Go Alex Pliutau

üõ† Code & Tools

doomgeneric: Doom, Ported to Go? ‚Äî If classic 90s FPS Doom can be ported to JavaScript and made to run inside a PDF, a Go port should be a piece of cake, right? Here‚Äôs a little slice of magic involving using the ccgo C-to-Go¬†compiler. Don't get too excited though as it's a limited proof of concept and Linux only, but it's neat to see what ccgo is capable¬†of.

cznic

golang-set: A Simple, Well-Tested, Generic Set Type ‚Äî ‚ÄúUntil Go has sets built-in‚Ä¶use this.‚Äù The latest v2.8 release adds support for Go 1.23‚Äôs range-over-func¬†iteration.

Ralph Caraveo

üîí Protect Against AI Bots, Fraud, and Abuse in Real Time ‚Äî WorkOS Radar protects your app with advanced device fingerprinting ‚Äî stop fake signups, free tier abuse, bot attacks and brute force attempts¬†today.

WorkOS sponsor

DiceDB: A Reactive, In-Memory Database Optimized for Modern¬†Hardware ‚Äî A new Go-powered database! Dice is a reactive database where your clients subscribe to receive changes immediately and it seems to take a lot of inspiration from the Redis approach being both in-memory and with simple Redis-like commands. GitHub¬†repo.

DiceDB

Participle: A Simple Library for Defining Parsers ‚Äî Provides a straightforward yet idiomatic way to define parsers in Go using a familiar approach of using struct field tags to define a grammar, so if you‚Äôve used encoding/json before, you‚Äôre well on your¬†way.

Alec Thomas

  • Glamour 0.9 ‚Äì Stylesheet-based Markdown rendering for CLI apps, now with better syntax highlight and¬†tables.

  • Toxiproxy 2.12 ‚Äì Simulate 'chaotic' network conditions in both testing and development¬†environments.

  • üêç Viper 1.20 ‚Äì Config solution for Go apps supporting various file formats and environment¬†variables.

  • üì∞ Fusion 0.9 ‚Äì Lightweight, self-contained feed aggregator and reader. Built with Go, SQLite, and¬†Svelte.

  • go-github v70.0.0 ‚Äì Go client library for accessing the GitHub API v3.

  • River v0.19 ‚Äì Robust job processing system for Go and Postgres.

  • GoReleaser v2.8 ‚Äì Mostly improvements to the Pro version.

  • TOML 1.5 ‚Äì TOML config file parser for¬†Go.

„Äë
>>>>>>>>>

Damien Neil

item.title: „ÄêHow Swiss Tables make Go 1.24 faster„ÄëÁëûÂ£´Ê°åÂ≠êÂ¶Ç‰ΩïÊõ¥Âø´Âú∞1.24
item.description:
„Äê

#‚Äã544 ‚Äî March 5, 2025

Unsub¬†¬†|¬†¬†Web¬†Version

Go Weekly

Faster Go Maps with Swiss Tables ‚Äî One of Go‚Äôs newest features is a revamped map implementation powered by a new hash table algorithm called Swiss Table that boosts map operations up to 60% faster in microbenchmarks, while reducing memory overhead. Here‚Äôs a look at how it¬†works.

Michael Pratt

Tips to Debug Hanging Go Programs ‚Äî Next time your Go app becomes unresponsive, these tips can help you find the issue by forcing a stack trace or using Delve to attach to the process (or core dump) and revive the¬†program.

Michael Stapelberg

Keep Postgres Maintenance from Slowing Down Your Go App ‚Äî Secure your spot to learn the proactive maintenance practices that uncover hidden database performance risks, like slow queries, checkpoint behavior, & connection issues, before they¬†escalate.

pganalyze sponsor

The Cost of Go's panic and recover ‚Äî When something goes unexpectedly and critically wrong in a Go program you might use panic to abort things quickly, but did you know you can use recover to manage what happens after a panic? This means you could use it as a sort of control flow mechanism, if you were in a particularly unorthodox¬†mood..

Julien Cretel

üí° This post led to a rather extensive discussion on Hacker News.

IN BRIEF:

  • üá¨üáß GopherConUK returns to London this August and its call for papers has just opened if you'd like to speak. You can submit a talk up until May¬†17.

  • go-attention is an attempt to create a pure Go implementation of attention mechanisms and transformer layers, such as used in modern¬†LLMs.

Calling Rust from 'Cursed' Go ‚Äî Cgo is Go‚Äôs mechanism for calling external/foreign functions but its performance often causes consternation. Enter purego, a still-in-beta way to make such calls without Cgo.

Preston Thorpe

Nil Channels in Go ‚Äî Nil channels seem to baffle many Gophers, so Vishnu went on a quest to figure out why in a particular case. This led him to the wisdom of a new Go proverb: ‚ÄúInit when you split; Nil when you¬†merge.‚Äù

Vishnu Bharathi

The Magic of Small Engineering Teams ‚Äî How PostHog uses small teams to ship fast and scale at the same¬†time.

PostHog sponsor

üìÑ Minesweeper with Raylib Go Bindings ‚Äì Alex reflects on the joys of basic game development in Go with Raylib and he shares his code¬†too. Alex Pliutau

üìÑ We Switched from Java to Go and Don't Regret It Miglinci, Steiner, and Enne (Glasskube)

üõ† Code & Tools

Gore 0.6: A Full Featured Go REPL Environment ‚Äî You get all the niceties you‚Äôd expect like line editing, history, multi-line input, the ability to import packages, and, in this latest build, gopls-powered code completion¬†too.

motemen

Go Clean Template ‚Äî Inspired by Uncle Bob‚Äôs ‚ÄòClean Code‚Äô principles, this repo attempts to provide a ‚Äòclean architecture template‚Äô for building Go-powered services that are well organized and won‚Äôt turn into a mess. You be the¬†judge.

Evrone

go-git 5.14: An Extensible Git Implementation in Pure Go ‚Äî ‚ÄúManipulate git repositories at low level (plumbing) or high level (porcelain), through an idiomatic Go API.‚Äù Now requires Go¬†1.23+.

go-git

sqldef 1.0: Idempotent Schema Management for Databases ‚Äî A Go-powered CLI tool and WASM library for diffing SQL schemas (demo here). Supports MySQL, Postgres, SQLite and SQL Server. Built by one of Ruby‚Äôs core team¬†members,¬†too.

Takashi Kokubun

  • ‚≠ê TinyGo 0.36.0 ‚Äì The much celebrated Go compiler 'for small places' gains Go 1.24 and LLVM 19 support, as well as support for several new¬†boards.

  • MongoDB Go Driver v2.1 ‚Äì Officially supported driver to work with MongoDB. Now supporting MongoDB's new bulk write API and BSON vector¬†datatype.

  • gocron v2.16.0 ‚Äì Job scheduling package for running Go functions at specified¬†intervals.

  • Wait4X 3.0 ‚Äì CLI tool for waiting on various ports or services to reach a specified¬†state.

  • pgroll v0.10 ‚Äì Tool for zero-downtime, reversible schema Postgres¬†migrations.

  • Glow 2.1 ‚Äì Terminal-based Markdown rendering from the folks at¬†Charm.

  • Pion WebRTC 4.0.13 ‚Äì Pure Go implementation of the WebRTC¬†API.

  • Sarama v1.45.1 ‚Äì IBM's Go client library for Apache¬†Kafka.

  • Hugo v0.145.0

üì∞¬†Classifieds

üìå Faster Deployment ‚Äì Integrate CarsXE‚Äôs API in minutes and get real-time vehicle data with ease. Try it now!¬†

Blacksmith runs GitHub Actions 2x faster at half the cost with a one-line code change. Trusted by 250+ companies like Ashby and¬†Clerk.

üì¢¬† Elsewhere in dev

A quick roundup of some of other interesting stories in the broader landscape, in case you've missed them:

  • ü§Ø Someone managed to implement 90s FPS game Doom entirely in the TypeScript type system.

  • And if you've never quite grokked how TypeScript ticks, Dr. Axel Rauschmayer has a succinct explanation of how it differs from JavaScript in a practical day-to-day tooling sense.

  • ü§ñ Microsoft and GitHub are getting into the 'AI developer agents' game and have showed off a look at GitHub Copilot 'agent mode' running in VS¬†Code.

  • Is it possible to think about game 'speedrunning' as essentially a form of vulnerability research?

„Äë
>>>>>>>>>

Motemen

evrone

- ‚ÄúÈÄöËøáÊÉØÁî®ÁöÑGO APIÊìçÁ∫µ‰ΩéÁ∫ßÂà´ÔºàÁÆ°ÈÅìÔºâÊàñÈ´òÁ∫ßÂà´ÔºàÁì∑Âô®ÔºâÁöÑGITÂ≠òÂÇ®Â∫ì„ÄÇ‚Äù Áé∞Âú®ÈúÄË¶Å1.23+„ÄÇ

„ÄÇ

- Áî®‰∫éÂàÜÊï£SQL SchemasÁöÑGo-Power CLIÂ∑•ÂÖ∑ÂíåWASMÂ∫ìÔºà

takashi kokubun

  • ‚≠ê tinygo 0.36.0 - Â§áÂèóÁû©ÁõÆÁöÑGo Compiler'Áî®‰∫éÂ∞èÂú∞ÊñπÁöÑÊî∂ÁõäËé∑Âæó1.24ÂíåLLVM 19ÁöÑÊîØÊåÅÔºå‰ª•ÂèäÂØπÂá†‰∏™Êñ∞Ëë£‰∫ã‰ºöÁöÑÊîØÊåÅ„ÄÇ

üì∞ÂàÜÁ±ª

üìåÊõ¥Âø´ÁöÑÈÉ®ÁΩ≤ - Âú®Âá†ÂàÜÈíüÂÜÖÈõÜÊàê‰∫ÜCarsxeÁöÑAPIÔºåÂπ∂ËΩªÊùæËé∑ÂèñÂÆûÊó∂ËΩ¶ËæÜÊï∞ÊçÆ„ÄÇ

item.title: „ÄêCleanups and weak pointers in Go 1.24„ÄëÊ∏ÖÁêÜÂíåËôöÂº±ÁöÑÊåáÈíà1.24
item.description:
„Äê

#‚Äã545 ‚Äî March 12, 2025

Unsub¬†¬†|¬†¬†Web¬†Version

Go Weekly

TypeScript's Compiler to Get 10x Faster, Thanks to Go ‚Äî TypeScript has shaken up the JavaScript ecosystem in recent years with an increasing number of developers relying on its strong typing and added structure. TypeScript‚Äôs compiler isn‚Äôt particularly fast, though, but the TypeScript team at Microsoft is changing that by porting it to¬†Go!

Anders Hejlsberg (Microsoft)

üì∫ The Syntax podcast had Anders on for an episode discussing the whole porting process. Lots of details for those who want to go¬†deeper.

Why Reimplement TypeScript's Compiler in Go? ‚Äî Many people have been asking why Microsoft is porting TypeScript‚Äôs compiler to Go rather than, say, Rust or C#. TypeScript‚Äôs architect Anders Hejlsberg delivered the definitive comment on the matter: Go fit the technical requirements and proved the best high performance language to which to port JavaScript for a variety of¬†reasons.

Microsoft's TypeScript Repo

üîí Protect Against AI Bots, Fraud, and Abuse in Real Time ‚Äî With WorkOS Radar you can detect, verify and block harmful behaviour, protecting your app with advanced device fingerprinting. Stop fake signups, stop free tier abuse, and stop bot attacks and brute force attempts¬†today.

Workos sponsor

New Low-Level Tools for Garbage Collection Efficiency ‚Äî A look at two new features offered by Go 1.24‚Äôs garbage collector: runtime.AddCleanup and weak.Pointer. Cleanups are like finalizers, but get around some of their quirks by not resurrecting objects they‚Äôre attached to. Weak pointers, meanwhile, let you reference objects without preventing their garbage¬†collection.

Michael Knyszek

üí° The Go team has updated the Go garbage collector docs with info about the above¬†features.

Different Ways of Working with SQL Databases in Go ‚Äî Starting with a simple schema presenting a basic blog system, Alex walks through a variety of approaches from working with raw SQL and database/sql to sqlx, using ORMs, and sqlc.

Alex Pliutau

Building a Secure Session Manager ‚Äî The stateless nature of requests to a webapp demands some sort of session management, most commonly via a cookie containing a unique ID to identify the user. Mohamed looks at a way to keep this whole process¬†secure.

Mohamed Said

üí° Mohamed follows on with Implementing Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) Protection in Go Web¬†Apps.

Using Cursor for Large Projects ‚Äî If you‚Äôve tried using tools like Cursor to write Go code in larger projects, you‚Äôll have almost certainly run into its limitations. Thierry has some tips for adding a bit of structure to the ghost in the¬†machine.

Thierry S. (Stream)

Sign Up for a Workshop to Get Started Building Go-Powered Decentralized Apps ‚Äî App builders, Go enthusiasts, tinkerers: come and build on gno‚Ä§land, a smart contract platform for a freer, fairer¬†world.

gno‚Ä§land sponsor

üìÑ Building Cross-Platform SDKs: From FFI to WebAssembly ‚Äì Another story where Cgo reared its ugly head and forced a different¬†approach. Mark Phelps (Flipt)

üìÑ The Benefits of Native FIPS Support in Go 1.24 Derek Parker (Red Hat)

üõ† Code & Tools

RobotGo: Native Cross-Platform GUI Automation ‚Äî A way to control the pointer, keyboard, read the screen, etc. Combine this with an LLM perhaps.. if you¬†dare?

V Caesar et al.

ghw 0.15.0: A Go Hardware Discovery/Inspection Library ‚Äî Find out things about the memory, CPU, storage, network support, and similar things about the host computer. Focused on Linux and Windows, with partial macOS¬†support.

Jay Pipes

ObjectBox Go 1.9: A Fast, Embedded Database for Go Objects ‚Äî Store objects in ObjectBox and find them again using powerful¬†queries.

ObjectBox Ltd.

  • ü§ñ Ollama v0.6 ‚Äì Tool for running and managing large language models. v0.6 adds support for Google's new Gemma 3 model.

  • Gum v0.16 ‚Äì Tool for creating stylish shell scripts with customizable utilities.

  • Semantic Search 0.4 ‚Äì Library for embedded vector searching and semantic embedding generation with¬†llama.cpp.

  • Ark 0.3 ‚Äì Entity Component System (ECS) for¬†Go.

  • Microsoft's Builds of Go 1.24.1-1 and 1.23.7-1

üì∞¬†Classifieds

Infrastructure Identity: A New Paradigm for Trustworthy Computing in a Zero Trust World ‚Äì Download your copy¬†here.

üëÄ Give your eyes a break! MonoLisa makes coding more comfortable. Try MonoLisa¬†now.

üì¢¬† Elsewhere in dev

A quick roundup of some other interesting stories in the broader landscape, in case you've missed them:

  • The HTTP Archive has finished publishing their Web Almanac for 2024, a fantastic resource of information about how technologies are really used on the modern Web in areas as diverse as HTTP support, security, and¬†JavaScript.

  • A developer is facing potential jail time for deploying a 'kill switch' into his employer's systems to perform nefarious actions if he were to be removed from the company's staff directory.

  • üêò If you've got Postgres SQL query plans you need to analyze, these are some of the tools to try.

  • ü§ñ Esteemed LLM-whisperer Simon Willison drops a ton of insights and tips on how he uses LLMs to help him write code.

„Äë
>>>>>>>>>

delivered the definitive comment on the matter: Go fit the technical requirements and proved the best high performance language to which to port JavaScript for a variety of¬†reasons.

MicrosoftÁöÑÊâìÂ≠óÁ®ørepo

- ‰ΩøÁî®WorkosÈõ∑ËææÔºåÊÇ®ÂèØ‰ª•Ê£ÄÊµãÔºåÈ™åËØÅÂíåÈòªÊ≠¢ÊúâÂÆ≥Ë°å‰∏∫ÔºåÂπ∂‰ΩøÁî®È´òÁ∫ßËÆæÂ§áÊåáÁ∫π‰øùÊä§ÊÇ®ÁöÑÂ∫îÁî®Á®ãÂ∫è„ÄÇÂÅúÊ≠¢‰º™ÈÄ†ÁöÑÊ≥®ÂÜåÔºåÂÅúÊ≠¢Ëá™Áî±Á∫ßÂà´Êª•Áî®ÔºåÂÅúÊ≠¢Êú∫Âô®‰∫∫ÊîªÂáªÂíåËõÆÂäõÂ∞ùËØï„ÄÇ

workos

Êñ∞ÁöÑ‰ΩéÁ∫ßÂ∑•ÂÖ∑Áî®‰∫éÂûÉÂúæÊî∂ÈõÜÊïàÁéá - Êü•ÁúãGo 1.24ÁöÑÂûÉÂúæÊî∂ÈõÜÂô®Êèê‰æõÁöÑ‰∏§‰∏™Êñ∞ÂäüËÉΩÔºö Runtime.AddCleanUp and code> feek.pointer.pointer.pointer.pointer.pointer>„ÄÇpointer>„ÄÇpointer>„ÄÇÂêåÊó∂ÔºåÂ∞ÜÂÆÉ‰ª¨Âõ∫ÂÆöÂú®Âº±ÊåáÈíà‰∏äÁöÑÁâ©‰Ωì‰∏≠

Michael Knyszek

üí°GOÂõ¢ÈòüÂ∑≤Êõ¥Êñ∞‰∫ÜGOÂûÉÂúæÊî∂ÈõÜÂô®ÊñáÊ°£

‰∏≠ÁöÑÊï∞ÊçÆÂ∫ì - ‰ªé‰∏Ä‰∏™ÁÆÄÂçïÁöÑÊû∂ÊûÑÂºÄÂßãÔºåÂ±ïÁ§∫Âü∫Êú¨ÁöÑÂçöÂÆ¢Á≥ªÁªüÔºåAlexÊµèËßà‰∫ÜÂêÑÁßçÊñπÊ≥ïÔºå‰ªé‰ΩøÁî®RAW SQLÂíå database/sql Âà∞ sqlx Ôºå‰ΩøÁî®ORMSÂíå sqlc> sqlc sqlc „ÄÇ

Alex pliutau

Á©ÜÁΩïÈªòÂæ∑ËØ¥

üí°Á©ÜÁΩïÈªòÂæ∑ÔºàMohamedÔºâÈÅµÂæ™Âú®GO WebÂ∫îÁî®‰∏≠ÂÆûÊñΩË∑®Á´ôÁÇπËØ∑Ê±Ç‰º™ÈÄ†ÔºàCSRFÔºâ‰øùÊä§„ÄÇ

item.title: „Äêgopls can now suggest ways to modernize your Go code„ÄëGOPLÁé∞Âú®ÂèØ‰ª•Âª∫ËÆÆÊÇ®Áé∞‰ª£ÂåñGO‰ª£Á†ÅÁöÑÊñπÊ≥ï
item.description:
„Äê

#‚Äã543 ‚Äî February 26, 2025

Unsub¬†¬†|¬†¬†Web¬†Version

Go Weekly

Testing Concurrent Code with testing/synctest ‚Äî Concurrency is one of Go‚Äôs natural strengths, but testing heavily concurrent programs can be tricky. Go 1.24 introduces a new (though experimental and hidden behind an environment variable) package for testing code involving time or concurrency. The Go team wants you to have a play and send in your¬†feedback.

Damien Neil

Prepare Your App for AI Agents ‚Äî Stytch extends auth to handle permissions for AI agents‚Äîso your app can securely delegate access to agents or protect against agent-powered threats. Check out our Go¬†quickstart.

Stytch sponsor

Extensible Wasm Applications with Go ‚Äî ‚Äú‚Ä¶ the ability to build a WASI reactor and export Go functions to Wasm in Go 1.24 represent a significant step forward for Go‚Äôs WebAssembly capabilities. These features empower developers to create more versatile and powerful Go-based Wasm applications ‚Ä¶‚Äù

Cherry Mui

IN BRIEF:

  • Go's LSP server (gopls) has a new version out that adds a modernize analyzer that can suggest ways your Go code could be updated to take advantage of new language features and standard library¬†APIs.

  • Ben Boyter's Searchcode code search engine is a fantastic project and it's now powered entirely by Go and an epic 6 terabyte SQLite file.

  • Former core team member Brad Fitzpatrick ran into a memory leak with unique.Handle and has written up his findings.

  • üì∫ Go had its own track at the recent FOSDEM conference and you can enjoy videos of most of the talks here. Topics covered included eBPF, garbage collection, gRPC, and how Go 1.24's swiss maps implementation works. (I find the player on this site very flaky, but the 'Download' option works fine.)

  • üá™üá∫ GopherCon Europe 2025 is.. a go! It takes place this June in¬†Berlin.

How to Manage Tool Dependencies in Go 1.24+ ‚Äî We‚Äôve touched on the new go tool subcommand a few times before, but this is a bit more usage-focused and includes a nice tip about separating your tools into their own module¬†file.

Alex Edwards

gno.land Offers Grants & Bounties for Building Go-Powered Decentralized Apps ‚Äî App builders, Go enthusiasts, tinkerers: come and build on gno.land, a smart contract platform for a freer, fairer¬†world.

gno.land sponsor

üìÑ Building RAG Systems in Go with Ent, Atlas, and pgvector Rotem Tamir (Ent)

üìÑ Building a BitTorrent Client from the Ground Up in Go ‚Äì We linked this in 2020 but it‚Äôs been doing the rounds on social media again and is fun to¬†revisit. Jesse Li

üì∫ From Strong to Weak: Weak Pointers in Go 1.24 Flo Woelki

üìÑ Scaling gRPC with Kubernetes and Go Noam Yadgar

üìÑ Practical OpenAPI in Go Alex Pliutau

üõ† Code & Tools

Minecraft From Scratch: A Simple Go Minecraft Clone ‚Äî A fun project to replicate Minecraft‚Äôs infinite, procedurally-generated navigable landscapes using Go and OpenGL 4.1 (as provided via the go-gl/gl bindings ‚Äì yes, cgo is required¬†here).

Gianluca Piccirillo

nativewebp: Native WebP Image Support for Go ‚Äî WebP is a modern raster graphics format commonly used on the Web and this library lets you work with it (though only its VP8L lossless form, for now) from Go without dependencies.

Hugo Smits

WAX: JSX-Based Server-Side Rendering for Go ‚Äî Generate server-side HTML with TSX/JSX templates in¬†Go.

Kita

godoc.nvim: Fuzzy Search Go's Docs from Neovim ‚Äî Adds a quick way to search and browse Go documentation from within the Neovim editor.

Fredrik Averpil

GoChromecast: Discover Devices and Stream Media to Chromecast Devices ‚Äî A Go-powered tool that implements the protocol used by Chromecast¬†devices.

Vjeran

  • FastHTTP 1.59 ‚Äì Performance-oriented alternative to net/http for specific high-volume¬†scenarios.

  • Sloc Cloc and Code (scc) 3.5 ‚Äì Fast and accurate code counter with complexity calculations and COCOMO¬†calculations.

  • wazero 1.9 ‚Äì Zero dependency WebAssembly runtime for¬†Go. Now boasting Go 1.24¬†compatibility.

  • Revive 1.7 ‚Äì Fast, configurable, extensible, flexible linter for¬†Go.

  • Go-MySQL-Driver 1.9 ‚Äì MySQL driver for¬†database/sql.

  • graphql-go 1.6 ‚Äì GraphQL server with a focus on ease of use

  • River 0.18 ‚Äì Fast and reliable Postgres-powered background jobs for¬†Go.

  • üîé errcheck 1.9 ‚Äì Checks for unchecked errors in Go¬†code.

  • ü§ñ Gobot 2.5 ‚Äì The robotics / drones / IoT¬†framework.

  • ü§ñ Go OpenAI 1.38 ‚Äì An OpenAI API wrapper¬†library.

  • Go gRPC Middleware 2.3

üì∞¬†Classifieds

üî• Free. As in zero dollars. Why haven‚Äôt you signed up? Get instant access to CarsXE‚Äôs API with a free trial. No risk, just great data. Try for Free¬†now!

Elevate Infrastructure Resiliency and Engineering Velocity with Infrastructure¬†Identity.

üì¢¬† Elsewhere in dev

A quick roundup of some of other interesting stories in the broader landscape, in case you've missed them:

  • Anthropic released Claude 3.7, a new version of its popular large language model, and reports and benchmarks so far show it's really good for coding.

  • An interesting look at how Git's core contributors configure their own git¬†setups.

  • Browser developers collaborate via a project called Interop and focus on features to bring to the Web platform each year. Interop 2025's priorities include the Storage Access API, CSS improvements, WebAssembly enhancements, and¬†more.

  • The XOR operator, and logic gate, explained. (You can use bitwise XOR yourself in Go with the ^ operator.)

„Äë
